revision.text:
{{Use British English|date=August 2011}} {{Use dmy dates|date=August 2011}} {{Infobox artist | name = Richard Parkes Bonington | honorific_suffix = | image = Portrait of Richard Parkes Bonington.jpg | image_size = 200px | alt = | caption = Portrait of Richard Parkes Bonington by [[Alexandre-Marie Colin]] | native_name = | native_name_lang = | birth_name = | birth_date = 25 October 1802 | birth_place = [[Arnold, Nottinghamshire]], England | death_date = 23 September 1828 | death_place = France | resting_place = | resting_place_coordinates = | nationality = British/ French | residence = | education = [[École des Beaux-Arts]], Paris | alma_mater = | known_for = | notable_works = | style = | movement = [[Orientalism|Orientalist]], Romanticism | spouse = | partner = | awards = | elected = | patrons = | memorials = | website = | module = }} '''Richard Parkes Bonington''' (25 October 1802 – 23 September 1828) was an English [[Romanticism (art)|Romantic]] [[Landscape art|landscape]] painter, who moved to France at the age of 14 and can also be considered as a French artist, and an intermediary bringing aspects of English style to France.Novotny, 171 Becoming, after his very early death, one of the most influential British artists of his time, the facility of his style was inspired by the old masters, yet was entirely modern in its application. His landscapes were mostly of coastal scenes, with a low horizon and large sky, showing a brilliant handling of light and atmosphere. He also painted small historical [[cabinet painting]]s in a freely-handled version of the [[troubadour style]]. ==Life and work== [[File:Richard Parkes Bonington 003.jpg|thumb|240px|''[[Francis I of France|François I]] and [[Marguerite de Navarre]]'' (45.7 by 34.5 cm), based on the discovery of a scratched inscription on a window at the [[Château de Chambord]]]] Richard Parkes Bonington was born in the town of [[Arnold, Nottinghamshire|Arnold]], four miles from [[Nottingham]]."Arnold" in ''[[Chambers's Encyclopædia]]''. London: [[George Newnes]], 1961, Vol. 1, p. 633. His father also known as Richard was successively a gaoler, a drawing master and lace-maker, and his mother a teacher. Bonington learned watercolour painting from his father and exhibited paintings at the [[Liverpool Academy of Arts|Liverpool Academy]] at the age of eleven. In 1817, Bonington's family moved to [[Calais]], France, where his father had set up a lace factory. At this time, Bonington started taking lessons from the painter [[François Louis Thomas Francia]],Ingamells, 19 who, having recently returned from England, where he had been deeply influenced by the work of [[Thomas Girtin]],Binyon, pp.166 – 7 taught him the English watercolour technique. In 1818, the Bonington family moved to Paris to open a lace shop. There he met and became friends with [[Eugène Delacroix]]. He worked for a time producing copies of Dutch and Flemish landscapes in the [[Louvre]]. In 1820, he started attending the [[École des Beaux-Arts]] in Paris, where he studied under [[Antoine-Jean, Baron Gros]]. It was around this time that Bonington started going on sketching tours in the suburbs of Paris and the surrounding countryside. His first paintings were exhibited at the Paris Salon in 1822. He also began to work in oils and lithography, illustrating [[Baron Isidore Justin Séverin Taylor|Baron Taylor]]'s ''Voyages pittoresques dans l'ancienne France'' and his own architectural series ''Restes et Fragmens''. In 1824, he won a gold medal at the Paris Salon along with [[John Constable]] and [[Anthony Vandyke Copley Fielding]], and spent most of the year painting coastal views in [[Dunkirk]]. In 1825 he met Delacroix on a visit with [[Alexandre-Marie Colin]] to London, and they sketched together there, and shared a studio for some months in Paris on their return; Delacroix influenced him in turning to historical painting. He also developed a technique mixing watercolour with [[gouache]] and gum, achieving an effect close to oil painting. In 1826 he visited northern Italy,Ingamells, 19-20 staying in Venice for a month,Binyon, pp. 169 and London again in 1827–8. In late 1828 his [[tuberculosis]] worsened and his parents sent him back to London for treatment. Bonington died of tuberculosis on 23 September 1828 at 29 Tottenham Street in London, aged 25. ==Reputation== [[File:Landscape near Quilleboeuf Richard Parkes Bonington.jpeg|thumb|right|240px|''Landscape near Quilleboeuf'', c. 1824–1825. [[Yale Center for British Art]]]] Delacroix paid tribute to Bonington's work in a letter to [[Théophile Thoré]] in 1861. It reads, in part:
When I met him for the first time, I too was very young and was making studies in the Louvre: this was around 1816 or 1817... Already in this genre (watercolor), which was an English novelty at that time, he had an astonishing ability... To my mind, one can find in other modern artists qualities of strength and of precision in rendering that are superior to those in Bonington's pictures, but no one in this modern school, and perhaps even before, has possessed that lightness of touch which, especially in watercolours, makes his works a type of diamond which flatters and ravishes the eye, independently of any subject and any imitation.Noon, Patrick: ''Richard Parkes Bonington "On the Pleasure of Painting"'', page 12. [[Yale University Press]], 1991.
To [[Laurence Binyon]] however, "Bonington's extraordinary technical gift was also his enemy. There is none of the interest of struggle in his painting." Bonington had a number of close followers, such as Roqueplan and Isabey in France, and [[Thomas Shotter Boys]], James Holland, [[William Callow]] and [[John Scarlett Davis]] in England. In addition, there were many copies and forgeries of his work made in the period immediately after his death.{{cite book|title=Watercolours|first=Graham|last=Reynolds|series=World of Art|publisher=Thames and Hudson|location=London|page=108|year=1998|origyear=1971 (as ''A Concise History of Watercolour''))}} A statue to him was erected outside the [[Nottingham Trent University, School of Art and Design|Nottingham School of Art]] by [[Watson Fothergill]], and a theatre{{cite web|title=Arnold|url=http://www.gedling.gov.uk/businesslicensing/towncentres/arnold/|work=Gedling Borough Council website|publisher=Gedling Borough Council|accessdate=21 May 2014}} and primary school in his home town of [[Arnold, Nottinghamshire|Arnold]] are named after him. In addition, the house in which he was born (79 High Street, Arnold) is now named ‘Bonington House’ and is Grade II [[Listed building|listed]].{{cite web|title=Listed Buildings|url=http://www.gedling.gov.uk/media/documents/planningbuildingcontrol/listed_buildings_GedlingBor.pdf|publisher=Gedling Borough Council|accessdate=21 May 2014|author=Gedling Borough Council Planning and Environment Department Local Plans Section|date=6 December 2005}} The [[Wallace Collection]] has an especially large group of 35 works, representing both his landscapes and [[history painting]]s. ==Gallery==
File:Richard Parkes Bonington - Rouen - WGA02431.jpg|[[Rouen]] Image:Richard Parkes Bonington 005.jpg|''Normandy'', c. 1823 Image:Richard Parkes Bonington 001.jpg|''View of the Lagoon Near Venice'', 1827. [[Louvre]] File:Richard Parkes Bonington Venice Grand Canal.jpg|''Venice, Grand Canal'' File:Charles V visits François Ier after the Battle of Pavia.jpg|''Charles V. visits François Ier after the Battle of Pavia'', c. 1827
==References and sources== ;References {{reflist}} ;Sources *{{cite book|last=Binyon|first=Laurence|title=English Watercolours|year=1933|publisher=A&C Black| location=London}} *Cambridge, M (2002). ''Richard Parkes Bonington: Young and Romantic.'' Nottingham: Nottingham Castle {{ISBN|0-905634-58-6}} (Catalogue of exhibition at [[Nottingham Castle]] Museum in 2002; contains an account of the life and works that includes many references.) *Ingamells, John, ''The Wallace Collection, Catalogue of Pictures, Vol I, British, German, Italian, Spanish'', Wallace Collection, 1985, {{ISBN|0-900785-16-0}} *{{cite book|last=Novotny|first=Fritz|title=Painting and Sculpture in Europe, 1780-1880|authorlink=Fritz Novotny|series=Pelican History of Art|publisher=Yale University Press|edition=2nd|year=1971|isbn=0-14-056120-X}} ==Further reading== *Noon, P (2009). ''Richard Parkes Bonington : the complete paintings.'' New Haven, Yale University Press. {{ISBN|0-300-13421-5}} ==See also== * [[List of Orientalist artists]] * [[Orientalism]] ==External links== {{commons category|Richard Parkes Bonington}} * [http://www.handprint.com/HP/WCL/artist08.html Handprint.com – Biography by Bruce MacEvoy.] Retrieved 17 November 2004. *[http://www.tate.org.uk/servlet/ArtistWorks?cgroupid=999999961&artistid=41&page=1 Works by Bonington] in the Tate Gallery] *[http://wallacelive.wallacecollection.org/eMuseumPlus?service=ExternalSearch&module=collection&fulltext=bonington Works by Bonington in the Wallace Collection] {{Authority control}} {{Romanticism}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Bonington, Richard Parkes}} [[Category:1802 births]] [[Category:1828 deaths]] [[Category:19th-century English painters]] [[Category:19th-century deaths from tuberculosis]] [[Category:Burials at Kensal Green Cemetery]] [[Category:English male painters]] [[Category:English romantic painters]] [[Category:English watercolourists]] [[Category:Infectious disease deaths in England]] [[Category:Landscape artists]] [[Category:Orientalism]] [[Category:Orientalist painters]] [[Category:People from Arnold, Nottinghamshire]] [[Category:Pupils of Antoine-Jean Gros]]

page.title: Royal Scottish Society of Painters in Watercolour

revision.text:
{{primarysources|date=July 2007}} The '''Royal Scottish Society of Painters in Watercolours''' (RSW) is a [[Scotland|Scottish]] organisation of painters.
It was founded in 1876, with the support of the [[Royal Scottish Academy]], by artists to "promote, through exhibition, the medium of watercolour and encourage the bold, free and colourful qualities of Scottish Painting."<ref>From organisation's website at [http://www.thersw.org.uk/history.asp]</ref>
The society received permission from [[Queen Victoria]] to use the prefix "Royal" in 1886 and throughout its history many renowned artists have been members, including [[Sam Bough]], [[David McClure (artist)|David McClure]], [[William McTaggart]], [[Adam Bruce Thomson]], [[Claire Harrigan]], [[George Paul Chalmers]], Alison Dunlop, [[Elizabeth Blackadder]] and [[Barbara Rae]].
Past presidents include William J L Baillie (1975–1988), Ian McKenzie Smith (1988–1998), Philip T L Reeves (1998–2005), John Inglis (2005–2016); the current president is Jim Dunbar.
Past vice presidents include Alison Dunlop, Helga Chart, Gregor Smith and Iona Montgomery.
== See also == * [[Royal Watercolour Society]] * [[Royal Institute of Painters in Water Colours]] * [[Visual Arts Scotland]]
== External links == * [http://www.rsw.org.uk/ Organization homepage]
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Royal Scottish Society of Painters in Watercolour}} [[Category:Scottish watercolourists| ]] [[Category:19th-century art groups]] [[Category:1876 establishments in Scotland]] [[Category:Scottish art]] [[Category:Organisations based in Scotland with royal patronage|Society of Painters in Watercolour]] [[Category:Scottish artist groups and collectives]]

revision.comment: Typo/[[WP:DATE|date]]/[[WP:AWB/GF|general]] fixes, replaced: womens' → women's, 1560's → 1560s, [[WP:AWB/T|typo(s) fixed]]: grand-daughter → granddaughter using [[Project:AWB|AWB]]
revision.text:
{{Infobox artwork | image_file=Vecelli, Tiziano - Judith - c. 1515.jpg | image_upright=1.182 | title=Salome | artist=[[Titian]] | year = c. 1515 | medium=Oil on canvas | height_metric=90 | width_metric=72 | city=[[Rome]] | museum=[[Doria Pamphilj Gallery]] }} '''''Salome''''' is an oil painting, probably of [[Salome]] with the head of [[John the Baptist]], by the Italian late [[Renaissance]] painter [[Titian]]. It is usually dated to around 1515 and is now in the [[Doria Pamphilj Gallery]] in [[Rome]]. Like other paintings of this subject,<ref>Ciletti, 50</ref> it has sometimes been considered to represent ''[[Book of Judith|Judith]] with the Head of [[Holofernes]]'', the other biblical incident found in art showing a female and a severed male head .<ref>DP. Safarik's official guide of 1993 calls it "''Judith with the Head of Holofernes'' (known as ''Salome'')", but in 2017 the museum website called it ''Salome''. See below also.</ref> Historically, the main figure has also been called [[Herodias]], the mother of Salome.
Sometimes attributed to [[Giorgione]], the painting is now usually seen as one where Titian's personal style can be seen in development, with a "sense of physical proximity and involvement of the viewer", in which "expert handling of the malleable oil medium enabled the artist to evoke the sensation of softly spun hair upon creamy flesh".<ref>Jaffé, 72</ref>
[[Erwin Panofsky]] suggested the head of John the Baptist might be a self-portrait,<ref>Robertson, 220; Hale, 147; Neginsky, 96 quotes him, 98-99; Falomir</ref> and it is possible that Titian was alluding to his private life with the model, anticipating [[Cristofano Allori]]'s, ''Judith with the Head of Holofernes'' (1613, [[Royal Collection]], and other versions), where the severed head was a self-portrait and Judith and the maid portraits of his ex-mistress and her mother.<ref>Neginsky, 96</ref> The model here, allowing for a degree of idealization, has been said to be the same used in the ''[[Dresden Venus]]'' (Giorgione and Titian, c. 1510).<ref>Hale, 147; Robertson, 219</ref><!-- as well as other Titians of the period, including the ''[[Woman at the Mirror]]'', ''[[Violante (Titian)|Violante]]'', ''[[Vanity (Titian)|Vanity]]'' and ''[[Sacred and Profane Love]]''. NO REF, & doesn't look much like them to me -->
This composition was copied many times, in some cases at least by Titian's workshop.<ref>Norton; Robertson, 219</ref>
==Salome, Judith or Herodias?== [[File:Titian-salome.jpg|thumb|Lighter image, with clearer view of the background cupid and fittings]] The possible [[provenance]] of the painting begins in 1533, with a ''Judith'' by Titian recorded in the collection of [[Alfonso I d'Este, Duke of Ferrara]], a very important patron of Titian. No other surviving Titian painting seems to fit this record, so if it is not the painting now in Rome, it must be lost.<ref>Safarik, 12</ref> In 1592 Duke Alfonso's granddaughter, [[Lucrezia d'Este (1535–1598)]] owned a painting described as a "[[Herodias]]" (Salome's mother).<ref>Again, that this is the same painting is uncertain, but endorsed by Safarik, apparently [[Harold Wethey]], and others.</ref> What is certainly the Doria Pamphilj painting belonged by 1603 to Cardinal [[Pietro Aldobrandini]] before passing to his niece [[Olimpia Aldobrandini]], whose second husband was the ex-cardinal [[Camillo Pamphilj]]; since then it has passed by descent through the family.<ref>DP</ref> In the 18th century the painting was called a ''Herodias'', but a number of foreign visitors who saw it record thinking the main figure to be Judith.<ref>Safarik, 12</ref>
If the painting's main figure was Herodias, traditionally seen as the prime mover of the conspiracy to get John the Baptist executed, the younger woman next to her would be intended to represent her daughter Salome,<ref>Safarik, 12</ref> here shown as a figure in thrall to her more glamourous mother. The identification as Herodias seems to have no recent supporters, but that as Judith does.<ref>Including: Joannides, 250; Safarik, 12, and Peter Humfrey in his ''Titian'', 2007, which lists it as "Judith (?), c. 1516"</ref>
A medieval addition to the Salome legend held that, as well as her mother's hatred of John for his preaching against her, Salome was also motivated by a frustrated love for John, to which the cupid might refer.<ref>Neginsky, 96-98</ref> Her face is turned away from his head, but her eyes look back to it. Panofsky describes her as: "Meditative, sad and a little benumbed, she seems to recoil from the face of St. John which yet attracts her sidelong glances with irresistible force". Meanwhile, the maid "looks at the heroine with the eyes of a faithful dog who feels and shares his master's distress without comprehending its cause".<ref>Panofsky, quoted in Neginsky, 96</ref> Thus, in the pyramidal group of figures,<ref>Falomir</ref> the glances flow from the maid on the left, up to Salome at centre, and down to John at right, whose dead eyes are closed.
The use of erotic allure on male figures of power is the core of both stories, but to the church and Titian's contemporaries, Herodias and Salome were bad, but Judith a heroine.<ref>Safarik, 12</ref> Both stories were part of the repertoire of the [[Power of Women]] topos, mainly a feature of German art in this period, but whose subjects were also depicted in Italy.<ref>Ciletti, 35-52 and especially 45-52</ref> The small [[Cupid]] at the top of the arch reinforces the eroticism of the treatment, suggesting either Salome's lust for John,<ref>Neginsky, 96</ref> (or Herod's implied attraction to Salome) or that of Holfernes for Judith,<ref>Joannides, 250</ref> according to choice. It has also been suggested that the use of cupids on the keystone of arches was common in public buildings of the period in Venice, which "stresses the official nature of St. John's imprisonment and execution".<ref>Robertson, 219-220</ref>
The presence of a maidservant is usual in depictions of Judith (following the [[Book of Judith]], which mentions her), but not in those of Salome with the head of [[John the Baptist]].<ref>Hall, 173-174, 181. But there are exceptions both ways - Judith with no maid, Salome with one. See Joannides, 250</ref> On the other hand, the head on a dish is normally associated with Salome's story, and is mentioned in the gospel,<ref>Mark: 6, 21-18</ref> while Judith often puts hers in a sack, or carries it by the hair, both also following the text of their story.<ref>[[Book of Judith]], Chapter 13, 9-10: "After which, she went out and gave the head of Holofernes to her maid, who put it in her food bag", and after their return, 15: "She pulled the head out of the bag and held it for them to see.", [http://www.catholic.org/bible/book.php?id=18&bible_chapter=13 online]</ref> A single lock of hair falling over the face was considered highly alluring, and associated with courtesans, perhaps suggesting Salome is indeed the subject,<ref>Hale, 147; Jaffé, 72</ref> though Judith is described as using every effort to dress seductively.<ref>Judith, Ch 10: "3 There she removed the sackcloth she was wearing and taking off her widow's dress, she washed all over, anointed herself plentifully with perfumes, dressed her hair, wrapped a turban round it and put on the robe of joy she used to wear when her husband Manasseh was alive. 4 She put sandals on her feet, put on her necklaces, bracelets, rings, earrings and all her jewellery, and made herself beautiful enough to beguile the eye of any man who saw her."</ref>
The murky background at the left includes a fitting at the top, between the two women's heads, which is described as a lock by Panofsky, though it might be a hinge also.<ref>Neginsky, 96</ref> This marks the vertical edge of a zone with a slightly different tint, perhaps showing the transition from a door to a wall. What could be an iron bar, or door top, is to the left of the fitting. The Pasadena version also shows a fitting and change in colour. This suggests the paintings show the women leaving the prison where John was killed, to return with the head to the head to Herod's feast, a version of the story often shown in art, though not exactly following the gospel, in which a soldier presents the head on a dish to Herod, who gives it to Salome, who in turn gives it to her mother.<ref>Mark 6, 21-28: "So the king immediately sent a bodyguard and commanded him to bring John’s head. So he went off and beheaded him in the prison and brought his head on a platter. He gave it to the girl, and the girl gave it to her mother."</ref> The biblical text is very clear that Holofernes is assassinated in his tent in his camp, and the scene (rare in art) where Judith shows the head to the people of [[Bethulia]] happens at night inside the city gate, so the background of the painting is difficult to reconcile with a depiction of Judith.
==Attribution and date== As with other small Titians from the 1510s, the attribution has wavered over the centuries, beginning with Titian in early records, but (almost inevitably) becoming attributed to [[Giorgione]] by the 19th century, until [[Crowe and Cavalcaselle]] attributed it to [[il Pordenone]]. By the end of that century it was once again attributed by most to Titian, which has remained the usual view among experts.<ref>Robertson, 219; DP</ref>
The [[Norton Simon Museum]] version was attributed to Titian in sales in England between 1801 and 1859, but a sale in London in 1891 called it a Giorgione.<ref>Norton</ref>
Though a date of about 1515 has long been the usual view, purely on stylistic grounds, [[Charles Hope (art historian)|Charles Hope]] has suggested about 1511. This is partly because of its relationship to [[Sebastiano del Piombo]]'s ''Salome'' of 1510 ([[National Gallery]]), where the setting also moves from dark at the left to light at the right.<ref>Robertson, 219; Hale, 147; [https://www.nationalgallery.org.uk/paintings/sebastiano-del-piombo-salome National Gallery page]</ref> This has also been regarded by some as a "Judith".<ref>Joannides, 250</ref>
==Context== [[File:Titian - Salome with Head of John the Baptist.png|thumb|Version in the Norton Simon Museum]] The painting relates to two different types of painting found in Venetian painting in the years dominated by Giorgione, including his posthumous influence. The first is a number of Venetian paintings of the 1510s showing two or three half-length figures with heads close together, often with their expressions and interactions enigmatic. Many of these are "Giorgionesque" genre or [[tronie]] subjects where the subjects are anonymous. But Titian's ''[[Lucretia and her Husband]]'' shows a specific subject, even if views differ as to the point in the story shown.<ref>See the discussion on the early copy in the [[Royal Collection]]: [https://www.royalcollection.org.uk/collection/402681/tarquin-and-lucretia Royal Collection], "After Titian (c. 1488-Venice 1576), ''Tarquin and Lucretia'', c. 1514–15, Oil on panel, RCIN 402681</ref> His ''[[The Bravo (Titian)|Bravo]]'' may have a specific subject;<ref>Jaffé, 98</ref> both of these are now in Vienna. ''The Lovers'' ([[Royal Collection]]) probably does not. His ''[[The Tribute Money (Titian)|Tribute Money]]'' (Dresden, c. 1516) has a clear subject, also from the New Testament.<ref>Jaffé, 98; Hale, 162</ref>
The other type it relates to is Titian's series of ''belle donne'' half-length female figures from the mid-1510s,<ref>Hale, 146-147</ref> which also includes ''Lucretia and her Husband'', as well as the single figures of ''[[Flora (Titian)|Flora]]'' at the [[Uffizi]],<ref>Jaffé, 96; Hale, 147</ref> the ''[[Woman with a Mirror]]'' at the [[Louvre]], the ''[[Violante (Titian)|Violante]]'' and ''[[Vanity (Titian)|Vanity]]'' in Munich. Most of these have the appearance of portraits, and were sometimes regarded as contemporaries as portraits of leading Venetian courtesans, but are best thought of as idealized figures of beautiful women which may only loosely reflect any individual. This type was more long-lived in Venetian painting, and made by many other artists; [[Palma Vecchio]] for one made a speciality of them.<ref>Jaffé, 96; Hale, 146</ref>
==Versions== There are several early repetitions that might be by Titian or his workshop, or both. A version now in the [[Norton Simon Museum]], [[Pasadena]] has been considered to be the best of the workshop versions. It was also in the Doria Pamphilj collection between Cardinal [[Pietro Aldobrandini]] at the start of the 17th century and 1797-98 during the French revolutionary invasion of Italy, when much Italian art was sold, mostly to the English, in anticipation of the French looting it otherwise. [[William Young Ottley]] was the initial purchaser, who took it to London and sold it in 1801.<ref>Safarik, 12; Norton</ref>
Another version that was part of the collections of Prince [[Salviati (bankers)|Salviati]], [[Christina of Sweden]] and of Prince [[Odescalchi]] is now owned by the real estate magnate [[Luke Brugnara]]. That Salome was also attributed to [[il Pordenone]] and Giorgione, and finally to Titian in the late 19th century.
==Other compositions of Salome and Judith== Titian painted Salome in at least one later composition, from the 1550s, with the dish holding the head held above her head ([[Prado]]), possibly using his daughter Lavinia as the model.<ref>Falomir; Neginsky, 99-100</ref> Another composition has recently resurfaced, which dates from the 1560s; as of 2012, this is in the [[National Museum of Western Art]], Tokyo.<ref>Falomir; [https://www.google.com/culturalinstitute/beta/asset/salome-with-the-head-of-john-the-baptist/-gE-LbtnmGl4tQ National Museum of Western Art] page on their version.</ref>
About 1570 Titian painted an undoubted ''Judith with the Head of Holofernes'' (now [[Detroit Institute of Arts]]).<ref>[https://www.dia.org/art/collection/object/judith-head-holofernes-63581 Detroit page]</ref>
== Notes == {{Reflist}}
== References == {{commonscat|Salome with the head of John the Baptist by Titian}} *Ciletti, Elena, "Patriarchal Ideology in the Renaissance Iconography of Judith", in Marilyn Migiel, Juliana Schiesari, eds., ''Refiguring Woman: Perspectives on Gender and the Italian Renaissance'', 1991, Cornell University Press, {{ISBN|080149771X}}, 9780801497711, [https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=ZMATQm0TLv0C&pg=PA35 google books] *"DP": [http://www.doriapamphilj.it/roma/en/i-capolavori-doria-pamphilj/tiziano-vecellio/ Page at the museum website] *Hale, Sheila, ''Titian, His Life'', 2012, Harper Press, {{ISBN|978-0-00717582-6}} *Hall, James, ''Hall's Dictionary of Subjects and Symbols in Art'', 1996 (2nd edn.), John Murray, {{ISBN|0719541476}} *Jaffé, David (ed), ''Titian'', The National Gallery Company/Yale, London 2003, {{ISBN|1 857099036}} (the painting was a late addition to this exhibition, not given a catalogue entry as such) *Joannides, Paul, ''Titian to 1518: The Assumption of Genius'', 2001, Yale University Press, {{ISBN|0300087217}}, 9780300087215, [https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=iz4iTAt16t4C&printsec=frontcover google books] *Neginsky, Rosina, ''Salome: The Image of a Woman Who Never Was'', 2014, Cambridge Scholars Publishing, {{ISBN|1443869627}}, 9781443869621, [https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=Fz1QBwAAQBAJ&pg=PA101 google books] *"Norton": [https://www.nortonsimon.org/art/detail/F.1965.1.066.P Norton Simon Museum page] ("Object Information" tab for provenance) *Falomir, Miguel, [https://www.museodelprado.es/en/the-collection/art-work/salome/0f359b90-2055-4326-bbbe-775dbfa7c504 Prado page on their version] (extract from book by Falomir, also covers the other two compositions) *Robertson, Giles, in Jane Martineau (ed), ''The Genius of Venice, 1500–1600'', 1983, [[Royal Academy of Arts]], London (Catalogue number 114) *Safarik, Eduard A., ''Galleria Doria Pamphilj, Masterpieces: Paintings'', Societa Arti Doria Pamphilj/Scala, 1993
==Further reading== * [[Erwin Panofsky|Panofsky, Erwin]], ''Problems in Titian, mostly Iconographic'', 1969
{{Titian}}

{{Use dmy dates|date=July 2018}} {{Infobox Museum |name =Sculpture Park Engelbrecht |image =Parc-55-Thumb-neu.jpg |imagesize =260 |caption =The Blacksmith I (Der Schmied I) |established =between 2002-2011 |dissolved = |location =Château des Fougis, 03220 Thionne, [[France]] |collections =Monumental massive steel sculptures by Erich Engelbrecht & a private exhibition with previous works by the same |map_type =France |pushpin_map =France |coordinates = {{coord|46.427000|3.564566|display=inline,Château des Fougis}} |visitors = |director =Waltraud Engelbrecht |curator = |publictransit = |website =[http://www.engelbrecht.art www.engelbrecht.art] or
[http://www.engelbrecht.fr/english/ www.engelbrecht.fr] }} {{Location map many |France Auvergne-Rhône-Alpes |region=FR-03 |width=260 |float=right | label =Les Fougis, Thionne | pos =bottom | mark=Red circle thick.svg | lat_deg =46.427082 | lon_deg =3.565506 | label2 = | pos2 = bottom | mark2=Flashspot.gif | lat2_deg =46.427082 | lon2_deg =3.565506 | label3 =Clermont | pos3 =bottom | mark3=Blue pog.svg | lat3_deg =45.777222 | lon3_deg =3.087025 | label4 =Lyon | pos4 =bottom | mark4=Blue pog.svg | lat4_deg =45.764043 | lon4_deg =4.835659 | label5 =Geneva | pos5 =bottom | mark5=Blue pog.svg | lat5_deg =46.204391 | lon5_deg =6.143158 | label6 =Grenoble | pos6 =bottom | mark6=Blue pog.svg | lat6_deg =45.188529 | lon6_deg =5.724524 |position=left |relief=1 |caption=Sculpture Park in the map of Auvergne-Rhône-Alpes. }} {{Location map many |France Allier |region=FR-03 |width=260 |float=right | label =Les Fougis, Thionne | pos =bottom | mark=Red circle thick.svg | lat_deg =46.427082 | lon_deg =3.565506 | label2 = | pos2 =bottom | mark2=Flashspot.gif | lat2_deg =46.427082 | lon2_deg =3.565506 | label3 =Moulins | pos3 =left | mark3=Blue pog.svg | lat3_deg =46.568059 | lon3_deg =3.334417 | label4 =Vichy | pos4 =above | mark4=Blue pog.svg | lat4_deg =46.131859 | lon4_deg =3.425488 |position=left |relief=1 |caption=Sculpture Park in the map of Allier. }} The '''Sculpture Park Erich Engelbrecht''' is located at the Château des Fougis, 03220 [[Thionne]], department of [[Allier]], France, and displays monumental massive steel sculptures of the German artist Erich Engelbrecht. In 2001, Erich Engelbrecht bought the property with the intent of installing his Sculpture Park throughout the gardens and former farming and hunting fields of Château des Fougis On loan from a private collection, the artist mounted also a second exhibition in the main wing of the castle, presenting some of his previous works like large-format tapestries, oil paintings, small steel figures and graphics. The open air exhibition at the Sculpture Park is open to public viewing. The indoor exhibition can only be visited following a previous private appointment. ==Les Fougis (the site)==
''“In the 15th century, according to tradition, '''Les Fougis''' were the hunting grounds of the Bourbons. In 1495 records exist of financial payments between {{nowrap|Duke Charles the 3rd}} and {{nowrap|Hughes le Long}}, Lord of Fougis and provost of the Duke’s Hunting. Earlier still, there’s a reference to the Lord of Fougis in an inventory written in 1410 by {{nowrap|Pierre Bodet}} for {{nowrap|Guichard Dauphin}}, Lord of Jaligny. In fact, the family le Long were the registered holders of {{nowrap|les Fougis}} from 1461 onwards, through squire {{nowrap|Hugonin le Long}}, who was also provost of the Hunting of {{nowrap|Pierre the 2nd}}. The {{nowrap|Le Longs}} retained the ownership of {{nowrap|Les Fougis}} until 1727, the date on which the territory was bequeathed to a nephew, {{nowrap|Jean Berthier de Bizy}}. Their descendants retained it until the French Revolution. In 1802 it was bought by {{nowrap|Antoine Clayeux}}, whose family owns the site to the present day.'' ''Rebuilt at the end of the 16th century (a doorway in classic style is dated 1593) the Fougis have walls pierced with more decorative openings. A description from {{nowrap|Nicolas de Nicolay}} in 1569 states {{nowrap|‘fort chasteau, terre et seigneurie…’}} (strong castle, land and lordship…)'' ''The château is composed of a main rectangular building, flanked by two square towers on its southwest and northeast corners, and a round tower to the southeast. A second perpendicular wing to the north is also flanked by another square tower on its east corner. The walls are made of red and dark brown brickwork, paired to form lozenge patterns. The openings are framed with white limestone. The north façade and some windows to the other sides were modified throughout the end of the 19th century.”''{{cite book |last1=GERMAIN |first1=Dominique LAURENT, Maurice PIBOULE, Anne REGOND... [et al.] ; sous la dir. de René |title=Châteaux, fiefs, mottes, maisons fortes et manoirs en Bourbonnais |date=2004 |publisher=Éditions De Borée |location=Romagnat |isbn=2-84494-199-0 |pages=539-540}}
At the turn of the 19th to the 20th centuries, the house was completely renovated and remodelled. The main courtyard received arcades on both wings, one of them with a glazed loggia. The north wing became an extra floor for the extended family and services. The interiors present a language typical for the period. After acquiring the property, Erich Engelbrecht undertook a multitude of renovation and building works on the fields and buildings to adapt Les Fougis for these exhibitions. Some of his family members settled in Fougis, where they presently live and work. ==Erich Engelbrecht (the artist)== '''Erich Engelbrecht''' ([[Bielefeld]], 27th October 1928 - [[Vichy]], France, 21st July 2011) was a German artist who left a [http://www.engelbrecht.fr/english/work/ multitude of works] in the fields of painting, graphics, tapestry, sculpture, architecture and poetry. Here is a selection of dates on [http://www.engelbrecht.fr/english/cv/ Erich Engelbrecht's bio:] {| |- ! scope="column"; style="vertical-align:top; text-align:left"|{{nowrap|'''1928'''}} |Born on 27th October in Bielefeld, Germany. |- |{{nowrap|'''1949-54'''}} |Studied Electrical Technology and different subjects in the field of Mechanical Engineering and Economics at the [[Technical University of Hannover]]. |- | |Contact with the [[Kestnergesellschaft]] in Hannover. |- |{{nowrap|'''1954-64'''}} |Worked intermittently as Industrial Consultant. |- |{{nowrap|'''1957'''}} |Degree as Doctor of Engineering at the Technical University of Hannover. |- |{{nowrap|'''1958-60'''}} |Studies in Philosophy and the History of Art at the [[University of Munich]]. |- | |Gets acquainted with the research and analytic of {{nowrap|[[CG Jung]]}}. |- |{{nowrap|'''1959'''}} |Marriage – four daughters. |- |{{nowrap|'''1960'''}} |First works of art using machine parts and rubber. |- |{{nowrap|'''1961'''}} |Rents a house in Holterdorf near [[Melle, Germany|Melle]] (Lower Saxony) as workshop, which he later buys and adapts to his home and workshop. |- | |During the same time, creation of the first, some very large oil paintings on canvas or wood panels. |- | |Among the paintings are also some wooden figures (oil on plywood, hanging in front of the walls.) |- |{{nowrap|'''1961-64'''}} |Winter sojourns in a second workshop in [[Locarno]]. |- |{{nowrap|'''1965'''}} |Establishment of the tapestry-weaving workshop in Holterdorf and manufacture of the first tapestries. |- |{{nowrap|'''1969'''}} |Engages with graphic work, first [[screen-printing|serigraphy]], later [[lithography]] and [[etching]]. Set up of an adjoining yarn dyeing workshop. |- |{{nowrap|'''1969'''}} |First individual exhibition in the {{nowrap|[[Kunsthalle Bielefeld]]}}. |- |{{nowrap|'''1972'''}} |Commission and construction of the first open air steel polychrom plastic in Bielefeld. |- |{{nowrap|'''1976'''}} |Creation of large coloured ceramic sculptures, wall mounted or inserted into the bottom of a pool. |- |{{nowrap|'''1982-84'''}} |Architecture project: Design and implementation of a house in Werther in the {{nowrap|[[Teutoburg Forest]]}}. |- |{{nowrap|'''1984-...'''}} |Design and construction of further large steel sculptures for the exterior as well smaller ones for the interior. |- |{{nowrap|'''1987'''}} |Large individual exhibition in the Gallery {{nowrap|[[Bernheim-Jeune]]}} in Paris. |- |{{nowrap|'''1996'''}} |Installation of large steel sculpture “Die Lektion” in {{nowrap|Melle-Neuenkirchen}} (Lower Saxony). Sale arrangements already in 1992. |- |{{nowrap|'''1997'''}} |Temporary exhibition of the sculptures {{nowrap|“The dancing Berserker”}} on the so-called {{nowrap|“Altona balcony”}} overlooking the river banks of the Elbe in [[Altona, Hamburg|Hamburg]]. |- |{{nowrap|'''2001-11'''}} |Planning and installation of a Sculpture Park on the gardens of the Château des Fougis in the [[Bourbonnais]], France. |- |{{nowrap|'''2011'''}} |Erich Engelbrecht dies on 21st July in Vichy. |- | |He rests on the Park of the Château of Fougis. |- |} ==Construction== The first sculptures arrived in 2002 and until his death in 2011 he managed to create an open exhibition of 29 large monumental and (mostly) coloured sculptures. The last sculpture - the smallest - arrived just after his death. All sculptures were produced in Germany and transported by road to Fougis, where they were finally assembled. Two sculptures positioned at the entrance of the park were created in 1984 and came to the present place after originally guarding the entrance of his property in Germany for nearly a decade and being exhibited in Hamburg-[[Altona, Hamburg|Altona]] (Altonaer Balkon) for nearly another decade. Belonging to a private collection, theses two sculptures are displayed on loan to the sculpture park. Some sculptures are distributed around the Château des Fougis, others follow a path designed by the artist. The indoor exhibition, a selection of large-format tapestries, oil paintings, small steel figures and graphics of Erich Engelbrecht, all on loan from a private collection, was imagined and installed between 2002 and 20011 by the artist himself and his wife Mrs Waltraud Engelbrecht. It is displayed throughout the galleries and the two main reception rooms of the Château des Fougis, which where specially renovated to receive these works. ==List of Sculptures== [[File:Fougis Plan 600.jpg|thumb|300px|Sculpture Park Engelbrecht - Plan]] List of Sculptures in the park with catalogue reference, original work and its date, date of arrival each sculpture in Fougis, dimensions (height & weight) and finishing {| class="wikitable sortable" |+ style="text-align:left"|List of works in the sculpture park |- !#!!Catal.!!Name!!O!!Date!!FR!!Height!!Weight!!Finishing |- style="vertical-align: top;" ! {{About|the stuffed monkey made from socks|the comic book|Sock Monkey}} [[File:Sock monkey.jpg|thumb|upright|A homemade sock monkey wearing a [[fez]] and scarf]]
A '''sock monkey''' is a [[stuffed toy]] made from socks fashioned in the likeness of a [[monkey]]. These stuffed animals are a mixture of [[folk art]] and [[kitsch]] in the [[culture of the United States|cultures of the United States]]<ref>{{cite news |title = History of the sock monkey – Stuffed animal created during the Great Depression |first = Janie |last = Boschma |date = 2007-11-05 |url = http://media.www.spectatornews.com/media/storage/paper218/news/2007/11/05/Showcase/History.Of.The.Sock.Monkey-3076934.shtml |newspaper = The Spectator |publisher = [[University of Wisconsin–Eau Claire]] |quote = sock monkeys have been part of American culture for nearly 100 years |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20091218185740/http://media.www.spectatornews.com/media/storage/paper218/news/2007/11/05/Showcase/History.Of.The.Sock.Monkey-3076934.shtml |archivedate = 2009-12-18 |df = }}</ref> and [[culture of Canada|Canada]]. The typical sock monkey is grey and white with extra long limbs, a long tail and bright red lips. The animal may be adorned with additional ornamentation on its head or around its neck. The character has become part of [[popular culture]] and can be found in [[Sock Monkey|comic books]] and art.
== Origin == The sock monkey's most direct predecessors originated in the [[Victorian era]], when the craze for imitation stuffed animals swept from Europe into North America and met the burgeoning [[Arts and Crafts Movement]]. Craft makers began sewing stuffed animals as toys to comfort children, and, as tales of the [[Scramble for Africa]] increased the public's familiarity with exotic species, monkey toys soon became a fixture of American nurseries. Tales like [[Rudyard Kipling|Rudyard Kipling's]] [[the Jungle Book]] and [[Just So Stories]] inspired crafters to create toys that depicted exotic animals,<ref name=":0">{{Cite book|title = Encounters with Popular Pasts: Cultural Heritage and Popular Culture|last = Robinson|first = Mike|publisher = Springer|year = 2015|isbn = 978-3-319-13183-2|location = New York|pages = 109–111|last2 = Silverman|first2 = Helaine}}</ref> however these early stuffed monkeys were not necessarily made from socks, and also lacked the characteristic red lips of the sock monkeys popular today.
John Nelson, a [[Sweden|Swedish]] immigrant to the United States, patented the sock-knitting machine in 1868, and began knitting socks on an automatic machine in [[Rockford, Illinois]] as early as 1870. On September 15, 1880, the Nelson Knitting Company formed, producing "Celebrated Rockford Seamless Hosiery," and selling them under the name of the "Nelson Sock."
John Nelson's son Franklin created a machine that knitted a sock without seams in the heel. The original machine required workers to sew every seam at the heel. The seamless sock saved time and labor costs and it became so popular, companies began to imitate his idea.<ref name=":0" /> These seamless work socks were so popular that the market was soon flooded with imitators, and socks of this type were known under the generic term "Rockfords".
The iconic sock monkeys made from red-heeled socks, known today as the ''Rockford Red Heel'', emerged at the earliest in 1932, the year the Nelson Knitting Company added the trademark red heel to its product. In 1932, advertising executive Howard Monk came up with an idea to change the heel of the brown sock from white to red. The red heeled sock was marketed as "de-tec-tip."<ref name=":0" /> Nelson Knitting added the red heel "De-Tec-Tip" to assure its customers that they were buying "original Rockfords" as opposed to the generic "Rockfords". This red heel gave the monkeys their distinctive mouth and during the [[Great Depression]], American crafters first made sock monkeys out of worn-out Rockford Red Heel Socks.
In 1953, a woman named Helen Cooke received the [[patent]] for sock monkeys. She sued a man named Stanley Levy because he sold sock monkeys but they were not the same design as hers. Levy contacted the Nelson Knitting Company hoping that they would declare the patent invalid. The company knew that people had been making dolls for the last two years, so they gathered up all the dolls that had been made the past two years so that they could have evidence proving that Helen Cooke should not have the patent. One of the most important pieces of evidence was a testimony and a doll made in February 1951 by a lady named Grace Wingent. She was a resident of Rockford and she had made a doll for her grandson. Helen Cooke settled the case against Stanley Levy when she was shown all the evidence that had been collected against her. She decided to sell the patent to the Nelson Knitting Company for $750. The company also paid other women for the rights to the doll including a woman in Tennessee who was paid $1000. Rockford, Illinois became the "home of the sock monkey."<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url = http://www.midwayvillage.com/wordpress/exhibits/the-missing-link-socks-monkeys-and-rockfords-industrial-past/|title = Sock Monkey Resource Packet|date = |accessdate = October 12, 2015|website = midwayvillage|publisher = |last = Midway Village Museum Collections Department|first = }}</ref>
== Today == [[File:Sock.monkey.ministries.2.jpg|thumb|left|upright|[[Servicemember]]s with sock monkeys made in [[Chelsea, Massachusetts]].]]
Sock monkeys remain a popular icon and are popular with all ages.<ref name="Creative Publishing International">{{cite book|title=Sew Cute and Collectible Sock Monkeys|date=June 2015|publisher=Creative Publishing International|isbn=9781589238664}}</ref> They now come in different styles, such as "birthday-themed", different colors, and even electronic ones that sing up-to-date [[pop songs]]. Most vintage red-heel sock monkeys found today are no older than the late 1950s, and many date from the 1970s.
A number of methods exist for dating red-heel sock monkeys, including the colors, shape of the red heel (elongated oval or swing), the amount of cream color in the red-heel and toe areas, sock seams, and interior sock content.<ref name="Creative Publishing International" />
The term "vintage" red-heel sock monkeys is typically relegated to sock monkeys made from red-heel socks knitted by the Nelson Knitting Company and from similar socks knitted with red-heels by other companies in the same time period. The term "modern" red-heel sock monkeys is normally relegated to sock monkey dolls created after [[Fox River Mills|Fox River Mills, Inc.]] acquired the Nelson Knitting Company in 1992.<ref name="Creative Publishing International" />
Homemade red-heel sock monkey dolls usually have unique faces and body characteristics and are considered one-of-a-kind. Sock monkey dolls are also mass-manufactured in the marketplace. Sock monkey dolls mass-manufactured by a company normally all have the same face and body characteristics. Not all sock monkey dolls are created from red-heel socks. A 2015 trend started to create sock monkey dolls from colorful striped or [[polka dot]] socks—even mismatched socks. <ref name="Creative Publishing International" />
People's love for sock monkeys has made the toys the center of many special occasions: trips, birthdays, anniversaries, weddings, and graduations to name a few, with their images now being used in photography, books, bookmarks, journals, greeting cards, jewelry, quilting, baking, sewing, commercials, movies, and more.<ref name="Creative Publishing International" />
Sock monkeys are found in literature: gift books like ''Monkey Love'',<ref>{{cite book|title=Monkey Love|publisher=Andrews McMeel Publishing|isbn=9780740754838}}</ref> and ''Friends Knock Your Socks Off'';<ref>{{cite book|title=Friends Knock Your Socks Off|publisher=Peter Pauper Press|isbn=9781593598983}}</ref> the children's novel ''The Secrets of Eastcliff-by-the-Sea'';<ref>{{cite book|title=Secrets of Eastcliff-by-the-Sea|publisher=Simon & Schuster|isbn=978-1442498402}}</ref> craft books such as ''Sew Cute and Collectible Sock Monkeys'';<ref>{{cite book|title=Sew Cute and Collectible Sock Monkeys|publisher=Creative Publishing International|isbn=9781589238664}}</ref> and they can be seen in [[Tony Millionaire|Tony Millionaire']]s [[Sock Monkey|graphic novel where a sock monkey is the main character]].<ref>{{Cite book|title = Everything's Coming up Sock Monkeys!: Art, History and Business of the American Sock Monkey|last = Connelly|first = Bonnie Kraus|publisher = In My Own Dream|year = 2006|isbn = 9780979032301|location = New York|pages = 110}}</ref> There's a film adaptation of Millionaire's comic currently in the works.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cartoonbrew.com/feature-film/tony-millionaires-sock-monkey-in-development-as-animated-feature-105537.html|title=Tony Millionaire’s ‘Sock Monkey’ in Development as Animated Feature|publisher=[[Cartoon Brew]]|author=Amid Amidi|date=November 13, 2014|accessdate=April 12, 2017}}</ref> They are also featured in the cover art for the 1992 alternative rock album "Dirty" by Sonic Youth.
One reason why sock monkeys are popular is that sock monkeys are said to be [[good luck charm]]s, and as a result, people offer sock monkeys as gifts. Sock monkeys have been given to patients in hospitals as a symbol of a quick recovery. They have been given to employees to relieve stress and sock monkeys have even been sent to soldiers overseas to relieve [[homesickness]].<ref>{{Cite book|title = Sew Cute and Collectible Sock Monkeys: For Red-heel Sock Monkey Crafters and Collectors|last = Lindner|first = Dee|publisher = Creative Publishing International|year = 2015|isbn = 978-1-58923-866-4|location = Minneapolis|pages = 13}}</ref>
In February 2015, Jody Lewis of [[Bridgwater]], [[Somerset|Somerset UK]], made the official [[Guinness world record]] for largest sock monkey made from individual socks. The sock monkey stands at 10 feet 5.59 inches.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.worldrecordacademy.com/biggest/largest_sock_monkey_Jody_Lewis_breaks_Guinness_World_Records_record_215434.html|title=Largest sock monkey: Jody Lewis breaks Guinness World Records record|website=www.worldrecordacademy.com|access-date=2017-12-19}}</ref>
== Festivals == The city of [[Rockford, Illinois]] embraces the doll as part of its history. In 2005, Midway Village Museum in Rockford held its first "Sock Monkey Madness Festival", where sock monkey fans could view an exhibit highlighting the industrial, legal, and creative history of the Nelson red-heel sock and the sock monkey. In 2009, the annual Sock Monkey Madness Festival was awarded a national Leadership in History Award of Merit from the American Association for State and Local History for excellence in educational programming.
The Sock Monkey Madness Festival also includes the original sock monkey that helped the Nelson Knitting Company win the [[patent]] and obtain the title “Home of the Sock Monkey.” Additionally, there is a 7-foot-2-inch sock monkey named "Nelson" (he acquired his namesake after the founder of the factory, John Nelson). Nelson, the super-sized sock monkey mascot created by author/crafter Dee Lindner was sewn out of 44 Rockford red-heeled socks.<ref name=":1" /> Furthermore, the festival is kid friendly and has unique attractions such as the “Sockford General Hospital”. The hospital is a “crafty clinic” that repairs sock monkeys if they require any care. Volunteers dress as nurses and fix any button eyes that fall off, torn mouths, or do any other sewing that is necessary.<ref>Dooley, Jenna "(Sock) Monkey Business: A Festival For An Iconic Toy." ''Weekend All Things Considered (NPR)'' 12 March 2012. ''Regional Business News Plus''. Web. 12 Oct. 2015.</ref>

{{italictitle}} '''''The Banksias''''', by [[Celia Rosser]], is a three-volume series of monographs containing paintings of every ''[[Banksia]]'' species. Its publication represented the first time such a large genus had been entirely painted by a single [[botanical artist]]. It has been described as "one of the outstanding botanical works of this century."<ref name="Nokomis">{{cite web | url = http://nokomis.com.au/banksias.html | title = The Banksias | accessdate = 2007-03-25}}</ref>
The paintings themselves are [[watercolour painting|watercolours]] on Arches rag paper. The three volumes comprise plates reproduced using [[offset printing]], and bound in green leather.<ref name="Studio International">{{cite web | url = http://www.studio-international.co.uk/painting/banksias.asp | title = The Banksias: Watercolours | publisher = Studio International | accessdate = 2007-03-25}}</ref> [[Alex George]] wrote the accompanying text.
Rosser began working on the series in 1974. Volume I of ''The Banksias'', containing 24 plates, was published in 1981. The edition comprised 730 books and 100 portfolios. Volume II, published in 1988, also contained 24 plates and was also released in an edition of 730 books and 100 portfolios. Volume III, completed in 2000, contained 28 plates, and was released in an edition of 530 books and 300 portfolios.<ref name="Studio International"/> Since the publication of Volume III, a new ''Banksia'', ''[[Banksia rosserae|B. rosserae]]'' has been described; Rosser subsequently painted it and released a set of prints. In 2007, the genus ''[[Banksia ser. Dryandra|Dryandra]]'' was transferred to ''[[Banksia]]'', so there are now a great many ''Banksia'' species that have not been painted by Rosser.
Each volume of ''The Banksia''s has been presented to [[Elizabeth II of the United Kingdom|the Queen]] by the Australian Government as a gift of the Australian people. Largely on the basis of her work for ''The Banksias'', Rosser was awarded a Medal of the [[Order of Australia]] 1995 for her contribution to botanical art, and the [[Jill Smythies Award]] for botanical art in 1997.

{{Infobox musical artist | name = The Dazzle Dancers | image = | caption =The Dazzle Dancers performing in 2007 | image_size = | background = non_performing_personnel | origin = [[New York City]], [[New York (state)|New York]] | genre = | years_active = 1996–present | label = | associated_acts = | current_members = Cherry, Houdini Shalom, Dazzle, Vinnie, DT, Edible, Hole, Machine, Pretty Boy, Smokey D, Propecia Destiny, Robbie, Sochny, Negro Noir, Besamé, Rinky Dinky, Chunky Cupcake, Booty du Chef }}
'''The Dazzle Dancers''' are a performance group founded in 1996 in New York City's [[Tompkins Square Park]] during Wignot (the first year that [[Wigstock]] didn't happen in the park) by artist Mike Albo<ref>[http://www.harpercollins.com/authors/19468/Mike_Albo/index.aspx HarperCollins author biography, accessed July 21, 2009]</ref> (aka Dazzle Dazzle) and Grover Guinta<ref>[http://www.villagevoice.com/2002-07-23/columns/ny-mirror The ''Village Voice'', by [[Michael Musto]], July 23, 2002, accessed July 21, 2009]</ref> (aka Vinnie Dazzle). The male and female dancers appear in spare costumes or [[nude]] at festivals,<ref>[http://www.dazzledancers.com/press/artforum-artparade2006.jpg ''artforum'' magazine, September 9, 2006, accessed July 21, 2009]</ref> night clubs,<ref>[http://www.dazzledancers.com/press_nypress.html New York Press, Sept.25-Oct. 1, 2002, accessed July 21, 2009]</ref> and the [[Hipster (contemporary subculture)|Hipster]] scene.<ref>[http://www.dazzledancers.com/press/penthouse.jpg ''Penthouse'', December 2006, accessed July 21, 2009]</ref><ref>[http://nymag.com/nymetro/arts/features/n_8671/index2.htm ''New York Magazine', May 5, 2003, accessed July 21, 2009]</ref><ref>[http://www.villagevoice.com/2003-08-19/nyc-life/dancing-naked-in-the-dark/1 ''The Village Voice'', August 19, 2003, accessed July 21, 2009]</ref>
The Dazzle Dancers have performed nationally at many late-night clubs,<ref>[http://www.nypost.com/gossip/archives/2002/10/20021009_nude+dudes.htm New York Post, October 9, 2002, accessed July 21, 2009]</ref> [[Coney Island]] Amusement Park,<ref>[http://www.dazzledancers.com/press/nypost-coney.jpg New York Post, March 15, 2007, accessed July 21, 2009]</ref><ref>[http://www.dazzledancers.com/press/metro-coney.jpg New York Metro, March 15, 2007, accessed July 21, 2009]</ref><ref>[http://licktheweb.com/articles/reviews/dazzledancers.html Long Island ''Community Konnection'', accessed July 21, 2009]</ref> [[Wigstock]],<ref>[http://www.villagevoice.com/2005-08-16/nyc-life/angel-headed-hipsters-get-ready-for-wigstock/ The ''Village Voice'', August 16, 2005, accessed July 21, 2009]</ref> the [[Burning Man]] Festival in Nevada,<ref>[http://www.mccullagh.org/theme/dazzle-dancers.html Declan McCullagh Photography, accessed July 21, 2009]</ref> and onstage with the band [[Blondie (band)|Blondie]] to a crowd of 20,000 people at the Millennium New Year's Eve Celebration in Miami, Florida.
In 2005 the Dazzle Dancers were a central theme in a feature film, the romantic gay comedy ''[[Adam & Steve]]''.<ref>[http://www.adamandstevemovie.com/oldsite/castcrew.htm Official movie site, accessed July 21, 2009]</ref><ref>[http://www.adamandstevemovie.com/oldsite/castcrew.htm ''OutUK'' accessed July 21, 2009]</ref><ref>[https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0372122/ IMDB, accessed July 21, 2009]</ref>
Their costume designer is Matthew Flower, better known as Machine Dazzle, who has noted in an interview with [http://www.imaginefashion.com/ Imagine Fashion] that his designs are like sacred objects to him and believes in the transformative quality of costumes.<ref name="ImagineFashionMachineDazzle">[http://www.imaginefashion.com/ladies-gentlemen/sacred-objects-machine-dazzle ''Sacred Objects'']: Imagine Fashion interview with designer Machine Dazzle (2011)</ref>

{{Use dmy dates|date=June 2016}} {{Use British English|date=June 2016}} {{Infobox film | name = The Falling | image = TheFalling2014Poster.jpg | caption = UK theatrical release poster | director = [[Carol Morley]] | producer = {{plainlist| * [[Luc Roeg]] * [[Cairo Cannon]] }} | writer = Carol Morley | starring = {{plainlist| * [[Maisie Williams]] * [[Maxine Peake]] * [[Monica Dolan]] * [[Greta Scacchi]] * [[Mathew Baynton]] * [[Florence Pugh]] }} | music = [[Tracey Thorn]] | cinematography = [[Agnes Godard]]<ref>{{cite web |url=https://twitter.com/TheFalling_Film/status/572395654091300865 |title=''The Falling'' |work=[[Twitter]] |accessdate=24 March 2015}}</ref> | editing = Chris Wyatt | studio = {{plainlist| * [[BBC Films]] * [[British Film Institute]] }} | distributor = Metrodome UK | released = {{film date|df=yes|2014|10|11|London Film Festival}} | runtime = 102 minutes | country = United Kingdom | language = English | budget = £750,000<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.cineuropa.org/nw.aspx?t=newsdetail&l=en&did=246205 |title=Carol Morley begins ''The Falling'' |work=Cineuropa.org |accessdate=8 October 2014}}</ref> | gross = £468,762<ref>{{cite news |title=United Kingdom, US New Zealand Box Office |url=http://www.the-numbers.com/movie/Falling-The/New-Zealand#tab=international |work=[[The Numbers (website)|The Numbers]] |date=12 January 2016}}</ref> }} '''''The Falling''''' is a 2014 British mystery [[drama film]] written and directed by [[Carol Morley]]. It stars [[Maisie Williams]] and [[Florence Pugh]] as best friends at an all-girls school. The film also stars [[Greta Scacchi]], [[Monica Dolan]], [[Maxine Peake]], and [[Mathew Baynton]]. Production began in October 2013. The film premiered at the [[BFI London Film Festival]] on 11 October 2014 and was released theatrically on 24 April 2015 in the UK. ''The Falling'' earned £468,762 on a £750,000 budget.
== Plot == In 1969, Lydia and Abbie are best friends at an English girls school. Lydia, the neglected daughter of an [[agoraphobic]] mother, becomes fixated on Abbie, who has begun to explore her sexuality. After having sex with Lydia's brother Kenneth in an attempt to abort her pregnancy by another boy, Abbie begins to suffer from [[Mass psychogenic illness|fainting spells]]. She suffers an episode after a stint in detention with Lydia and dies in the process. Following Abbie's burial, Lydia begins suffering as well from fainting spells, and it soon becomes an epidemic, with numerous girls and a young teacher in the school spontaneously passing out for no more than a few seconds. Lydia becomes convinced that the administration must take action, much to the chagrin of the school principal.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/bbcfilms/articles/the_falling_begins_shoot |title=Independent Announces Start of Shoot for Carol Morley's Film ''The Falling'' |work=[[BBC Films]] |accessdate=8 October 2014}}</ref>
When an assembly becomes disrupted by a mass fainting episode, the school is temporarily shut down and all affected students are hospitalized and psychoanalysed. When no cause for the spells is discovered, the school is reopened and Lydia is expelled. That same night, the virginal Lydia has sex with Kenneth, with whom she has developed an incestuous relationship after Abbie's death. However their mother Eileen catches them and, armed with a pair of scissors, angrily forces Kenneth out of the house before launching into an argument with her daughter, in which she brands Lydia dangerous and that she ought to be locked up. Eileen also reveals that Lydia and Kenneth are only half-siblings; Lydia being the product of a rape.
Upon learning this, Lydia runs out of the house and Eileen follows her outside, despite having never ventured outside in over 16 years. Searching for Lydia, Eileen is overcome with flashbacks of her own sexual assault, and eventually locates Lydia; who has climbed to the top of a tree in a breakdown over Abbie's death. Eileen pleads with Lydia to come down, but she laughs, challenging her mother's lack of maternal affection, before losing her footing and leaping from the tree into a lake.
Distraught, Eileen ventures into the water and cradles Lydia's seemingly drowned body, realizing that her emotional frigidity had done more harm to her daughter than she knew. Lydia regains consciousness, and the film ends with the two women in a crying embrace.
== Cast == * [[Maisie Williams]] as Lydia Lamont * [[Maxine Peake]] as Eileen Lamb * [[Monica Dolan]] as Miss Alvaro * [[Greta Scacchi]] as Miss Mantel * [[Mathew Baynton]] as Mr Hopkins * [[Florence Pugh]] as Abigail Mortimer * [[Joe Cole (actor)|Joe Cole]] as Kenneth Lamont * [[Lauren McCrostie]] as Gwen * [[Rose Caton]] as Titch
== Production == BFI funded the film £750K.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.screendaily.com/news/get-santa-bill-get-1m-from-bfi/5063873.article |title=Get Santa, Bill get £1m from BFI |last=Wiseman |first=Andreas |work=[[Screen Daily]] |date=21 November 2013 |accessdate=8 October 2014}}</ref> Production began in October 2013.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.screendaily.com/news/carol-morleys-falling-underway/5062960.article |title=Carol Morley's ''The Falling'' underway |last=Wiseman |first=Andreas |work=[[Screen Daily]] |date=28 October 2013 |accessdate=8 October 2014}}</ref>
The soundtrack is by [[Tracey Thorn]]. Morley asked Thorn to provide the music for the film after editing had begun.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/film/2015/apr/21/carol-morley-tracey-thorn-the-falling|title=Carol Morley and Tracey Thorn: "Girls' schools? They’re a hotpot of urges"|author=Peter Bradshaw|work=the Guardian}}</ref>
== Release == ''The Falling'' premiered at the [[BFI London Film Festival]] on 11 October 2014.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://variety.com/2014/film/news/testament-of-youth-to-world-premiere-at-london-film-festival-1201296658 |title=''Testament of Youth'' to World Premiere at London Film Festival |last=Barraclough |first=Leo |work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]] |date=3 September 2014 |accessdate=8 October 2014}}</ref> It had a limited release in the United Kingdom, grossing £442,177 with a further £10,051 grossed in New Zealand.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.the-numbers.com/movie/Falling-The/New-Zealand#tab=international=summary |title=New Zealand Box Office for The Falling (2015)|work=The Numbers}}</ref> US DVD sales amounted to another £6,406.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.screendaily.com/news/metrodome-catches-carol-morleys-the-falling/5076917.article |title=Metrodome catches Carol Morley's ''The Falling'' |last=Wiseman |first=Andreas |work=[[Screen Daily]] |date=2 September 2014 |accessdate=8 October 2014}}</ref>
== Reception == [[Rotten Tomatoes]], a [[review aggregator]], reports that 78% of 22 surveyed critics gave the film a positive review; the average rating is 7/10.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/the_falling_2014/|title=The Falling (2015)|work=[[Rotten Tomatoes]]|accessdate=21 May 2015}}</ref> Mark Adams of ''[[Screen International]]'' wrote, "It is a film that will resonate with some but leave others exasperated, but ''The Falling'' is certainly a bold film, and one to be admired and appreciated."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.screendaily.com/reviews/the-latest/the-falling/5078546.article|title=The Falling|last=Adams|first=Mark|work=[[Screen International]]|date=11 October 2014|accessdate=24 April 2015}}</ref> Guy Lodge of ''[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]'' called it "an imperfect but alluring study of psychological contagion that marks an auspicious advance in the field of narrative filmmaking for acclaimed documaker Carol Morley".<ref>{{cite web|url=https://variety.com/2014/film/festivals/london-film-review-the-falling-1201331977/|title=London Film Review: ‘The Falling’|last=Lodge|first=Guy|work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|date=17 October 2014|accessdate=24 April 2015}}</ref> Leslie Felperin of ''[[The Hollywood Reporter]]'' called it "a flawed but fascinating period study of female friendship and hysteria".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/review/falling-london-review-740347|title=‘The Falling’: London Review|last=Felperin|first=Leslie|work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]|date=13 October 2014|accessdate=24 April 2015}}</ref> Trevor Johnston of ''[[Time Out (magazine)|Time Out London]]'' rated it 4/5 stars and wrote, "Carol Morley shows startling versatility and ambition with this jawdropping mash-up of ''[[If...|If]]'' and ''[[Picnic at Hanging Rock (film)|Picnic at Hanging Rock]]''".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.timeout.com/london/film/the-falling|title=The Falling|last=Johnston|first=Trevor|work=[[Time Out (magazine)|Time Out London]]|date=20 April 2015|accessdate=24 April 2015}}</ref> Mike McCahill of ''[[The Daily Telegraph]]'' rated it 4/5 stars and called it a continuation of the themes in [[Nicolas Roeg]]'s ''[[Performance (film)|Performance]]'' and ''[[Don't Look Now]]''.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/film/the-falling/review/|title=The Falling review: 'potently suggestive'|last=McCahill|first=Mike|work=[[The Daily Telegraph]]|date=24 April 2015|accessdate=24 April 2015}}</ref>
Geoffrey Macnab of ''[[The Independent]]'' rated it 4/5 stars and wrote, "Carol Morley's ''The Falling'' is beguiling and disturbing, a beautifully made and very subtle affair that combines melodrama, rites of passage and supernatural elements in an utterly intriguing way."<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/films/reviews/the-falling-film-review-top-of-the-class-for-melodrama-and-mystery-10199794.html|title=The Falling, film review: Maisie Williams is top of the class for melodrama and mystery|last=Macnab|first=Geoffrey|work=[[The Independent]]|date=24 April 2015|accessdate=24 April 2015}}</ref> [[Peter Bradshaw]] of ''[[The Guardian]]'' rated it 5/5 stars and wrote, "Director Carol Morley has come up with another brilliant and very distinctive feature, about an epidemic of fainting that grips a girls school in the 1960s."<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/film/2014/oct/10/the-falling-review-london-film-festival-carol-morley|title=The Falling review – Carol Morley's masterly followup to Dreams of a Life|work=[[The Guardian]]|date=10 October 2014|accessdate=24 April 2015}}</ref> Elise Nakhnikian of ''[[Slant Magazine]]'' gave a less favourable review, writing that "the film all leads to a melodramatic climax that wraps up the main character's explosive acting out in a too-neat package."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.slantmagazine.com/film/review/the-falling|title=The Falling|author=Elise Nakhnikian|date=23 August 2015|work=Slant Magazine}}</ref> David Jenkins of ''[[Little White Lies (magazine)|Little White Lies]]'' also gave an unfavourable review, writing, "Carol Morley follows up the mesmerising [[Dreams of a Life]] with a tedious period drama set in an all-girls school."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.littlewhitelies.co.uk/theatrical-reviews/the-falling-29408 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150919090744/http://www.littlewhitelies.co.uk/theatrical-reviews/the-falling-29408 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2015-09-19 |title=The Falling review |author=Little White Lies magazine|work=littlewhitelies.co.uk}}</ref>
== Awards == {| class="wikitable sortable" ! Award ! Category ! Nominee ! Result |- | [[London Film Festival]] 2014 | Best British Newcomer and Best Film || Florence Pugh and Official Competition Carol Morley || {{Nominated}} |- | [[London Film Critics' Circle]] || Young British/Irish Performer Of The Year || Maisie Williams<ref>http://www.criticscircle.org.uk/film/?ID=479</ref> || {{won}} |- | [[Evening Standard British Film Awards]] || Rising Star || Maisie Williams<ref>https://www.standard.co.uk/goingout/film/evening-standard-british-film-awards-2016-idris-elba-and-dame-maggie-smith-lead-list-of-winners-a3174206.html</ref> || {{won}} |- |}

revision.text:
'''''Allegories of the Five Senses''''' is a series of early 17th century painting by the Spanish artist [[Jusepe de Ribera]]. One of the series (''Hearing'') has been lost and is only known through copies. According the art historian [[Giulio Mancini]], a contemporary of the artist, their commissioner was Spanish but they were probably produced during Ribera's stay in Rome - Alfonso Pérez Sánchez dates their production to between 1611 and 1615{{sfn|Sánchez et Spinosa|p=60}}. File: Allegory of Smell Jose de Ribera.jpg|''Smell''
(115 cm x 88 cm), private collection File: Allegory of Sight Jose de Ribera.jpg|''Sight''
(114 x 89 cm) [[Franz Mayer Museum]], [[Mexico]]. File: José de Ribera - Sense of Taste - WGA19357.jpg|''Taste''
(113.8 cm x 88.3 cm), [[Wadsworth Atheneum]], [[Hartford, Connecticut]]. File: José de Ribera 018.jpg|''Touch''
(116 cm x 88.3 cm), [[Norton Simon Museum]], [[Pasadena]]. == References == == Bibliography == *Alfonso E. Pérez Sánchez and Nicola Spinosa, ''Jusepe de Ribera, 1591-1652'', New York, Metropolitan Museum of Art, 1992 ({{ISBN|0870996479}}) ==External links== *''[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=JCFRVaOZeAk Sight]'', [[Franz Mayer Museum]]. [[category:1610s paintings]] [[category:Paintings by Jusepe de Ribera]] [[category:Allegorical paintings]]
